content.question:
A GRAPHING CALCULATOR IS REQUIRED FOR THIS QUESTION.
You are permitted to use your calculator to solve an equation, find the derivative of a function at a point, or calculate the value of a definite integral. However, you must clearly indicate the setup of your question, namely the equation, function, or integral you are using. If you use other built-in features or programs, you must show the mathematical steps necessary to produce your results. Your work must be expressed in standard mathematical notation rather than calculator syntax.
Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.
Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.
Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>x</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> is a real number.

Let <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> be the functions defined by <math alttext=" f of x equals, the natural log of, open parenthesis, x plus 3, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mi>ln</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="g of x equals, x to the fourth power, plus 2, times x cubed" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>. The graphs of <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, shown in the figure, intersect at <math alttext="x equals negative 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mpadded><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn></mpadded></math> and <math alttext="x equals B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>B</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="B is greater than 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>B</mi><mo>></mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(a) Find the area of the region enclosed by the graphs of <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.

frqParts.text:
A GRAPHING CALCULATOR IS REQUIRED FOR THIS QUESTION.
You are permitted to use your calculator to solve an equation, find the derivative of a function at a point, or calculate the value of a definite integral. However, you must clearly indicate the setup of your question, namely the equation, function, or integral you are using. If you use other built-in features or programs, you must show the mathematical steps necessary to produce your results. Your work must be expressed in standard mathematical notation rather than calculator syntax.
Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.
Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.
Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>x</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> is a real number.

Let <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> be the functions defined by <math alttext=" f of x equals, the natural log of, open parenthesis, x plus 3, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mi>ln</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="g of x equals, x to the fourth power, plus 2, times x cubed" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>. The graphs of <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, shown in the figure, intersect at <math alttext="x equals negative 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mpadded><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn></mpadded></math> and <math alttext="x equals B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>B</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="B is greater than 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>B</mi><mo>></mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(a) Find the area of the region enclosed by the graphs of <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(b) For <math alttext="negative 2 less than or equal to x, less than or equal to B " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow><mo>≤</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><mi>B</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, let <math alttext="h of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> be the vertical distance between the graphs of <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Is <math alttext="h" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> increasing or decreasing at <math alttext="x equals negative 0.5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mpadded><mo>−</mo><mn>0.5</mn></mpadded></math> ?  Give a reason for your answer.

(c) The region enclosed by the graphs of <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is the base of a solid. Cross sections of the solid taken perpendicular to the <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-axis are squares. Find the volume of the solid.

(d) A vertical line in the <math alttext="x y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mspace></mspace><mi>y</mi></math>-plane travels from left to right along the base of the solid described in part (c). The vertical line is moving at a constant rate of <math alttext="7" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mn>7</mn></mrow></math> units per second. Find the rate of change of the area of the cross section above the vertical line with respect to time when the vertical line is at position <math alttext="x equals negative 0.5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mpadded><mo>−</mo><mn>0.5</mn></mpadded></math>.

skill.text: Skill 1.D: Identify an appropriate mathematical rule or procedure based on the relationship between concepts (e.g., rate of change and accumulation) or processes (e.g., differentiation and its inverse process, anti-differentiation) to solve problems.
